values:
Aforementioned vampire book is now on Chapter 6 and going very strong. I'm really happy with it so far ........  EXCEPT THAT IT'S TAKING OVER!!! I am getting new ideas all the time and I don't have time to write it all down!! so, I guess that is rather awesome.

So far, the people who've read what I've got really like it. Good sign? Find a more objective readership? WELL, not until it's DONE and I start pruning it, honey! Right now I am revelling in the write.

I've been reading voraciously all summer, until now when my summer classes are underway!
The idea for a new book sprang upon me while at work at the hospital...
let's just say for now that it involves vampires with Turkish or Arabic surnames, faceless government agents, blue-haired vegan protagonists and a wheelchaired sidekick. I'm so stoked on this one!

Today was the first class of my Creative Writing II class.

No writing happened, but let's just say that I'm stoked. Scribbley bits transcribed from the handwritten will appear shortly (:

These have 2004 dates. some days the past is easy to see, reflected in every                                                window. the laughing eyed girl, spinning 'round in circles concentric in a new dress made by her mother. the full skirt, her flower - the sunshine;                                        a crown if she falls, she rises never lingering, for freedom is the dress, the love, her mother's. and she?                         a princess.
time is moving, for me, like water. it feels so fluid fast short. i look up, each day, at the boxes on my wall, and i know that it will feel like only a moment until they are past. i feel that i should spend every moment of the last 3 weeks i have here happy but i can't, because the shadow of the day, the time, the date, the hour hangs over me like a mourning veil, obscuring my vision just enough that everything turns to grey. and right now i only feel like crying.
and one small random thing (this one sucks bad!) i sit here and look at the clock. i watch the hours go by - 8:30, 9:00, 10:00, 10:30, 11:00... and i feel horrible as the time slowly rolls by me, 10:30, 10:45. and i feel very terrible. like i am sitting here by a window as it rains and the clock beside me ticks slowly, slowly... and i feel that i am not a nice girl, for being so impatient, so upset... 10:45, 10:50.... and i wish i didn't feel this way, but i can't help it. i feel like i am forgotten. i'm sure there's a good reason, but for me, right now, all i have is the time. 10:50, 11:00, 11:15....

I know I haven't posted anything in a while -- that's because to be honest, I haven't been writing. I haven't been writing at all; not once, in all my adventures in Europe did I creatively write. I've been building experience and living my life and not writing.
I apologise.
I miss writing, so I have decided that in the spring, I will be taking Creative Writing II. This means I have to submit for publication. It's part of the course. I'm a little hesitant about that, but I am learning that I will never get anywhere without leaps of faith, so I am going to do it any how.
I am co-editor of the Skinny Voice, our department's underground zine, if you will. Right now I predict opinions making their way in, and I don't mind too much. I used to write opinions in high school all the time.
As it is, I just wanted to say -- I'll post in here when I'm writing again. And no, no it won't be poetry. Screw poetry. I hate it.

Today I peer edited with Paul, who I confess is pretty awesome. His opinion means a bit more to me than other students' in our class because I know he won't be nice and say "Oh, I love it" and offer nothing else. He edited both "Bottle Green" and "Photograph" for me. He had plenty of useful things to say about "Bottle Green", for which I was most grateful -- but he had only one thing to say about "Photograph"! I was really pleased because I prefer it to the other one and I expected...

Well, I don't know what I expected, but it was such a pleasant surprise. Needless to say I'm thrilled that it was received so well and I plan to do more in that vein with those characters. 

The Little Red Riding Hood manuscript is still coming along, although I haven't found a good title for it yet. I am no good with titles in general! Perhaps with a bit more time, something will come to me.

She read off a list of names to us and said pick one and write about them
I chose Alli Isom.

Response:
Alli Isom. Twenty-six years old, slightly blonde, computer technician. That's me all right, in the acorn of nutshell introductions. To be honest, I used to want to be a Rockette until I learned that I couldn't dance to save my soul.
No, really. I had a crazy dream involving Saint Peter, a bucket of raspberries and a foxtrot gone horribly wrong -- but that's not this story, because this story is about Jake.
Jake works with me. He debugs things, which may not sound exciting until you think about attention to detail. Jake is skinny and tall and he kind of reminds me of Olive Oil, you know, from those old cartoons?
Last summer Jake started to work for Brytec and things just haven't been the same since. Amy says it's my imagination, but I don't think she has a concept of what my imagination is like.

<strike>After all, I like to</strike>

Jake brought a lot of business in with him. A sudden boom, I'd say, except I never use onomatopoeia for anything if I can help it.
Our boss, Mr. Jones, says that it was his lucky day when he hired Jake.
I don't think he realises that I'm the one who brought Jake in. I met him at a diner and we started talking system boards --

Wait, stop that train of thought.

Assignment: add onto what was written for the Red Riding Hood prompt "Wa-hell," said the hitchiker, dusty from the road, "I'm on my own way to Tallahassee, miss --" "Red." She'd never been the most cautious of miniature adults, preferring instead to live a hard and fast lifestyle of spontaneity and car shows. She felt this man mighty fine despite shabby sport coat, and she told him so. His thanks was a feral grin and the offer of the name Lupus. The red convertible wound over the read, eating up the pavement inch by inch. "So, Mr. Lupus," Red asked, "Whatcha hitchikin' for?" Cinnamon gum snapped at the end of her sentence. Lupus just looked at her and smiled. He fed her some line about a workin' man and lack of a job, to which she simply nodded in understanding. Poor man, really. Poor Lupus indeed. The car was hot and Red sighed, letting her left hand drift out the open window. It dove through the air like a dolphin and she smiled to herself at the thought. "Lupus," she said. "Lupus, didja ever notice how your hand can just jump through the air?" No, Lupus reckoned he hadn't.

Prompt: Little Red Riding Hood is actually a little person, adult, and she is going to the grandmother's to find out if she is actually a dwarf or a midget. outlining: red riding hood... hood of a car? >> "showgirl"/cargirl.. "red"? car -- convertible drive across the States to Tallahassee wherein lies {rich, antiquated} grandmother picks up an opportunistic hitchiker named Lupus >> Levi Lupus Stella "Red" Starlight response: "Wa-hell," said the hitchiker, dusty from the road, "I'm on my own way to Tallahassee, miss --" "Red." She'd never been the most cautious of miniature adults, preferring instead to live a hard and fast lifestyle of spontaneity and car shows. She felt this man mighty fine despite shabby sport coat, and she told him so. His thanks was a feral grin and the offer of the name Lupus. The red convertible wound over the read, eating up the pavement inch by inch. "So, Mr. Lupus," Red asked, "Whatcha hitchikin' for?" Cinnamon gum snapped at the end of her sentence.

Once I woke 
     and
          I
realised I was not where I thought I was.
In three seconds I experienced about
Seventeen
          Emotional 
                    states.

november 10th, 2003 it's turned into winter, suddenly, the kind of days where the wind is blowing almost all the time and the sky is a clear sort of blue-grey that I've only seen in the irises of the eyes of special people. i missed autumn, somehow, it became trapped in the all the days when i forgot what i'd done right after i did it but it was never anything important at all. i wish I could have walked down my street while the leaves were changing in my black winter coat and my doc martens because it feels like autumn in that coat and those shoes and wavy hair that's faded from the last time i dyed it. i miss the way the leaves crush against the asphalt when they're dry and sad from falling off the tree that gave them life, but really i liked them better when they were yellow and orange and the colour of the edges of a fire when it's been burning for a while. i like the way the air smells here but it feels different here than winter does at home and i want to walk barefoot on the hardwood floors and smell something in the oven that maybe i helped make and maybe i didn't but it doesn't matter because i'll get to eat it anyway. i miss my piano keys and the way they feel against my fingers even when i'm not playing and the view out the kitchen window when there are deer in the yard. i'm happy here, but i missed autumn. it's winter, now, and autumn passed me by, the cinnamon pumpkin days skipped me and let the peppermint ones in first, in an odd display of courtesy when really i would have liked it better if they had been rude. the blinds on the open window keep banging against the window frame because it's hot with the heater on and even though we have it turned off my room is still stifling with warmth that could have been comfortable had i wanted it there - but i didn't. i drank peppermint hot chocolate today in a warm coffee shop and talked about dates instead of playing chess and i wished i could go someplace special in a pretty dress for no reason at all - but i can't because if i take myself, it's not the same. i want to eat curry and feed the ducks and swing in the park at night time when it's so cold that I'm shivering but i like it. mostly I want it to snow so that when i walk outside the ice will crunch under my shoes and i'll like it, because i never got over being a silly girl like that and i think i never will. because i like it.

I'm Kate.

I've never taken a class in creative writing. I've always, actually, thought of myself as a rather shitty writer. I'm not even sure why. This is, for all intensive purposes, both an experiment and a learning tool.

In this journal will be all my work from Creative Writing I, which I'm taking in the Spring of 2005, as well as some other work I'll do to get in "the swing" of writing before I start being graded.

We'll see how this all turns out.
